values.description:
Per Eric Krotkov’s request @faller and I have been working on improving the visual textures for the VRC arenas.

These changes are split into pull-requests across three repositories, please merge at the same time:

* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/26/new-vrc-textures/diff
* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/435/new-vrc-textures/diff
* #!/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/205/new-vrc-textures/diff

### Changelist: ###

* added texture to mud

* improved grass texture in manipulation and driving tasks

* added randomized texture to rubble

* changed texture sizes in heightmaps to improve resolution (also reduces increased parallax, the remaining parallax needs to be fixed by fixing heightmap or using a trimesh instead, see [gazebo issue 572](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/572/vrc-heightmap-problems))

* replaced grass texture in walking task heightmap

* added structured texture to valve, spigot, and hose coupling (color can be changed via material script) - not perfect but best we could do with the limited amount of time we have

* removed light from manipulation area in task3 to be able to see texture on objects properly

* turned off lighting for house_1 model as global lighting in driving task made it appear way too bright

* added brick texture to starting pen

* added brick wall between manipulation area and gas station

* changed initial camera view in vrc tasks to have better overview

### Pictures of new arenas:###

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task1.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view0.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view1.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view0.png

* http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view1.png

Everyone please feel free to give feedback / issue (reasonable) concerns if some change doesn’t work for your team or if you have a change yourself you want to contribute (I’ll give you write permissions to commit to the fork).

Thanks to Maurice (MIT) for collaborating and to Max (JPL) for providing feedback.

-Thomas
values.title: New VRC Textures

summary.html:
Per Eric Krotkov’s request @faller and I have been working on improving the visual textures for the VRC arenas.

These changes are split into pull-requests across three repositories, please merge at the same time:

  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/26/new-vrc-textures/diff
  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/435/new-vrc-textures/diff
  • #!/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/205/new-vrc-textures/diff

Changelist:

  • added texture to mud

  • improved grass texture in manipulation and driving tasks

  • added randomized texture to rubble

  • changed texture sizes in heightmaps to improve resolution (also reduces increased parallax, the remaining parallax needs to be fixed by fixing heightmap or using a trimesh instead, see gazebo issue 572)

  • replaced grass texture in walking task heightmap

  • added structured texture to valve, spigot, and hose coupling (color can be changed via material script) - not perfect but best we could do with the limited amount of time we have

  • removed light from manipulation area in task3 to be able to see texture on objects properly

  • turned off lighting for house_1 model as global lighting in driving task made it appear way too bright

  • added brick texture to starting pen

  • added brick wall between manipulation area and gas station

  • changed initial camera view in vrc tasks to have better overview

Pictures of new arenas:

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task1.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view0.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task2_view1.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view0.png

  • http://www.seas.upenn.edu/~thomasko/new_vrc_arenas/new_vrc_task3_view1.png

Everyone please feel free to give feedback / issue (reasonable) concerns if some change doesn’t work for your team or if you have a change yourself you want to contribute (I’ll give you write permissions to commit to the fork).

Thanks to Maurice (MIT) for collaborating and to Max (JPL) for providing feedback.

-Thomas

values.description:
Addresses issue #43 by adding an autogenerated `share/drcsim-x.y/.rosinstall` file.  This file can be used like so to create a workspace:

    rosinstall path/to/new/local/workspace install-prefix/share/drcsim-x.y

The `workspace` directory will include shell setup files suitable for building an overlay against drcsim.
values.title: Add .rosinstall file (issue #43)

summary.raw:

The `workspace` directory will include shell setup files suitable for building an overlay against drcsim.

Addresses issue #43 by adding an autogenerated share/drcsim-x.y/.rosinstall file. This file can be used like so to create a workspace:

rosinstall path/to/new/local/workspace install-prefix/share/drcsim-x.y

The workspace directory will include shell setup files suitable for building an overlay against drcsim.

values.description: This is an example mud model that can be tested with atlas. Note that the model name is hard-coded into the plugin link_name parameters, so it must be adjusted if used with atlas_sandia_hands or a model with a different name. It is not yet incorporated into any worlds, but it can be inserted using gzclient for testing. Please test with the gazebo branch in [pull request 448](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/448)

values.title: Fix issue 202

summary.html:
(from issue text) Issue #202

Right now any clients using the actionlib server will hang forever since the server does not report completion. At least right now I do not care about any of the feedback within, but just want my client to be able to know when it can send more footstep commands.

Adding 

this->actionServer->setSucceeded(actionServerResult);

to line 250 of actionlib_server.cpp would accomplish this. I suppose also 

this->actionServer->setAborted(actionServerResult);

should also be added to the appropriate cases within the switch statement of ASIActionServer::ASIStateCB()

values.reason:
I've put these changes into an issue_202 branch, that takes this a bit further. There shouldn't be hanging on the side of the actionlib_server, and addresses some other issues.

Thanks for the code!

values.description:
This pulls in John Hoare's suggestions about setting succeeded on the action server. It also prevents the commands from flooding the AtlasPlugin, which can cause the robot to fall over. 

Added in a check for control+c when polling input.
values.title: Fixes issue #202, issue #203 and issue #204

values.description:
Add the scoring plugin that will be used for Qualification.  The plugin is loaded in each of the `qual_task_[i].world` files, configured to write score data to `/tmp/qual_task_[i].score.log.

To test it:

* launch a qual world (e.g., `roslaunch atlas_utils qual_task_1.launch`)
* watch the score file (e.g., `tail -f /tmp/qual_task_1/score.log`)

For Q1, Q3, and Q4:

* drag/walk the robot through gates; you should see the completionScore value in the log file increment only when passing through the next gate, and only when going through it in the right direction
* drop/abuse the robot; when large acceleration is detected, you should see the falls value in the log file increment

For Q2:

* put the drill in the bin; you should see the completionScore value in the log file increment only when the drill enters the bin
* same fall behavior as for the others
values.title: Add VRCScoringPlugin

summary.raw:
Add the scoring plugin that will be used for Qualification.  The plugin is loaded in each of the `qual_task_[i].world` files, configured to write score data to `/tmp/qual_task_[i].score.log.

To test it:

* launch a qual world (e.g., `roslaunch atlas_utils qual_task_1.launch`)
* watch the score file (e.g., `tail -f /tmp/qual_task_1/score.log`)

For Q1, Q3, and Q4:

* drag/walk the robot through gates; you should see the completionScore value in the log file increment only when passing through the next gate, and only when going through it in the right direction
* drop/abuse the robot; when large acceleration is detected, you should see the falls value in the log file increment

For Q2:

* put the drill in the bin; you should see the completionScore value in the log file increment only when the drill enters the bin
* same fall behavior as for the others
summary.html:
Add the scoring plugin that will be used for Qualification. The plugin is loaded in each of the qual_task_[i].world files, configured to write score data to `/tmp/qual_task_[i].score.log.

To test it:

  • launch a qual world (e.g., roslaunch atlas_utils qual_task_1.launch)
  • watch the score file (e.g., tail -f /tmp/qual_task_1/score.log)

For Q1, Q3, and Q4:

  • drag/walk the robot through gates; you should see the completionScore value in the log file increment only when passing through the next gate, and only when going through it in the right direction
  • drop/abuse the robot; when large acceleration is detected, you should see the falls value in the log file increment

For Q2:

  • put the drill in the bin; you should see the completionScore value in the log file increment only when the drill enters the bin
  • same fall behavior as for the others

values.description:
The scripts to use for arenas testing which automatically start all logging mechanisms are inside test/ directory and only installed while at building time DRI capabilities are detected. This is preventing them from going into official packages.

I'm not sure if it would be a good idea to install them or keep for internal use just in the repo.
values.title: Consider moving atlas_arenas testing scripts to be included in packages

summary.raw:
The scripts to use for arenas testing which automatically start all logging mechanisms are inside test/ directory and only installed while at building time DRI capabilities are detected. This is preventing them from going into official packages.

I'm not sure if it would be a good idea to install them or keep for internal use just in the repo.
summary.html:
The scripts to use for arenas testing which automatically start all logging mechanisms are inside test/ directory and only installed while at building time DRI capabilities are detected. This is preventing them from going into official packages.

I'm not sure if it would be a good idea to install them or keep for internal use just in the repo.

values.reason:
I agree that those files should be installed, and that installation should be independent of whether there's a DRI display at configure time.  But I think that the files belong in the `test/` subdirectory, both in source and install.

Instead of the change proposed here, I suggest building on the [changes](#!/osrf/drcsim/pull-request/196/fix-tests-console-cleanup/diff#chg-ros/atlas_utils/test/CMakeLists.txt) in pull request #196, where all test files are always installed, but only executed if there's a DRI display.

values.description:
Enables an option to disable the dynamics of the sandia hands, so they are just stumps with fixed joints. Cameras are still enabled. This significantly improves real-time performance. This option has been added to quals 1 and 3, and vrc task 2.

To test, build [sandia-hand branch stumps_drcsim](#!/osrf/sandia-hand/compare/stumps_drcsim..default#diff) from source, then build drcsim.

Two arguments are required:

* hand_suffix:=_stumps
* gzworld:=*_task_n_stumps.world
~~~
roslaunch atlas_utils qual_task_1.launch gzworld:=qual_task_1_stumps.world hand_suffix:=_stumps

roslaunch atlas_utils qual_task_3.launch gzworld:=qual_task_3_stumps.world hand_suffix:=_stumps

roslaunch atlas_utils vrc_task_2.launch gzworld:=vrc_task_2_stumps.world hand_suffix:=_stumps
~~~

This pull request requires simultaneous release with sandia-hand.

UPDATE: update SandiaHandPlugin to retain publishers / subscribers
values.title: Sandia Hand stumps -- wait to merge this

summary.html:
Enables an option to disable the dynamics of the sandia hands, so they are just stumps with fixed joints. Cameras are still enabled. This significantly improves real-time performance. This option has been added to quals 1 and 3, and vrc task 2.

To test, build sandia-hand branch stumps_drcsim from source, then build drcsim.

Two arguments are required:

  • hand_suffix:=_stumps
  • gzworld:=*_task_n_stumps.world
roslaunch atlas_utils qual_task_1.launch gzworld:=qual_task_1_stumps.world hand_suffix:=_stumps

roslaunch atlas_utils qual_task_3.launch gzworld:=qual_task_3_stumps.world hand_suffix:=_stumps

roslaunch atlas_utils vrc_task_2.launch gzworld:=vrc_task_2_stumps.world hand_suffix:=_stumps

This pull request requires simultaneous release with sandia-hand.

UPDATE: update SandiaHandPlugin to retain publishers / subscribers

values.description:
By default, cheats (aka "development aids") are now disabled.  This is done by not advertising and not subscribing to the ROS topics associated with the cheats.

Cheats can be enabled by setting the environment variable `VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED` to `1`.  E.g., at the command-line:

    VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED=1 roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch

Or in a launch file:

    <launch>
      <env name="VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED" value="1"/>
      <include file="$(find atlas_utils)/launch/atlas.launch"/>
    </launch>

ROS API tests are included for both cheats enabled and cheats disabled for all supported launch files.
values.title: Remove cheats (issue #195)

summary.raw:
By default, cheats (aka "development aids") are now disabled.  This is done by not advertising and not subscribing to the ROS topics associated with the cheats.

Cheats can be enabled by setting the environment variable `VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED` to `1`.  E.g., at the command-line:

    VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED=1 roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch

Or in a launch file:

    <launch>
      <env name="VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED" value="1"/>
      <include file="$(find atlas_utils)/launch/atlas.launch"/>
    </launch>

ROS API tests are included for both cheats enabled and cheats disabled for all supported launch files.
summary.html:
By default, cheats (aka "development aids") are now disabled. This is done by not advertising and not subscribing to the ROS topics associated with the cheats.

Cheats can be enabled by setting the environment variable VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED to 1. E.g., at the command-line:

VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED=1 roslaunch atlas_utils atlas.launch

Or in a launch file:

<launch>
  <env name="VRC_CHEATS_ENABLED" value="1"/>
  <include file="$(find atlas_utils)/launch/atlas.launch"/>
</launch>

ROS API tests are included for both cheats enabled and cheats disabled for all supported launch files.

values.description:
Per issue #213, install `ros/atlas_description/manifest.xml` to `share/drcsim-X.Y/ros/atlas_description`.  Also make the manifest.xml files in the subdirectories under `share/drcsim-X.Y/gazebo_models/atlas_description` into real ROS manifests.

There's more manifest cleanup to be done in the install tree, but I'm not doing it now because it's not apparently urgent.

(This doesn't need to be reviewed yet; it'll be included in the review of `vrc3_hose_update`.)

This change is needed by the scoring system to prevent out-of-order execution of tasks (also it adds a bit of realism in that you usually have a hard time connecting a hose to a running faucet).

values.description:
A variety of changes needed to score during competition (as opposed to qualification).

To try it:

    roslaunch atlas_utils vrc_task_2.launch

Move/drag the robot through some gates.  There will be a log file, `/tmp/vrc_task_1/score.log`, with content like this:

    # Score data for world vrc_task_2
    # Started at: 1366926176.753
    # Format: 
    # wallTime(sec),simTime(sec),wallTimeElapsed(sec),simTimeElapsed(sec),completionScore(count),falls(count)
    1366926179.891,1.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926182.343,2.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926184.338,3.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926186.419,4.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926188.518,5.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926190.582,6.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926192.617,7.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926194.394,7.877,0.000,0.000,1,0,"Successfully passed through gate 0"
    1366926197.168,8.877,2.774,1.000,1,0,""
    1366926198.848,9.522,4.454,1.645,2,0,"Successfully passed through gate 1"

The elapsed times (3rd and 4th fields) are the times elapsed from passing through the first gate.

That data will also be published along the way on the ROS topic `/vrc_score` in a message of type [atlas_msgs/VRCScore](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/846e683437437b2f68373b3596b9513f6a1609c7/ros/atlas_msgs/msg/VRCScore.msg?at=vrc_scoring_updates).

Arena-specific rules:

* V1: Atlas must pass through the first gate, then the vehicle must pass through the next two gates, then Atlas must pass through the last gate.  1 point per gate.
* V2: Atlas must pass through the gates in order. 1 point per gate.
* V3: Atlas must:
    * pass through the first gate (no points, but starts clock), then
    * get the hose coupler up to around the height of the standpipe (1 point), then
    * get the hose coupler aligned well enough to the standpipe to cause the invisible screw joint to be created (1 point), then
    * rotate hose coupler clockwise until it has traveled at least 1.5cm travel into the screw joint (about 2.38 rotations) (1 point), then
    * open valve by rotating it counterclockwise at least 1 full rotation (1 point).
values.title: Update scoring for VRC

summary.raw:
A variety of changes needed to score during competition (as opposed to qualification).

To try it:

    roslaunch atlas_utils vrc_task_2.launch

Move/drag the robot through some gates.  There will be a log file, `/tmp/vrc_task_1/score.log`, with content like this:

    # Score data for world vrc_task_2
    # Started at: 1366926176.753
    # Format: 
    # wallTime(sec),simTime(sec),wallTimeElapsed(sec),simTimeElapsed(sec),completionScore(count),falls(count)
    1366926179.891,1.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926182.343,2.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926184.338,3.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926186.419,4.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926188.518,5.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926190.582,6.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926192.617,7.000,0.000,0.000,0,0,""
    1366926194.394,7.877,0.000,0.000,1,0,"Successfully passed through gate 0"
    1366926197.168,8.877,2.774,1.000,1,0,""
    1366926198.848,9.522,4.454,1.645,2,0,"Successfully passed through gate 1"

The elapsed times (3rd and 4th fields) are the times elapsed from passing through the first gate.

That data will also be published along the way on the ROS topic `/vrc_score` in a message of type [atlas_msgs/VRCScore](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/846e683437437b2f68373b3596b9513f6a1609c7/ros/atlas_msgs/msg/VRCScore.msg?at=vrc_scoring_updates).

Arena-specific rules:

* V1: Atlas must pass through the first gate, then the vehicle must pass through the next two gates, then Atlas must pass through the last gate.  1 point per gate.
* V2: Atlas must pass through the gates in order. 1 point per gate.
* V3: Atlas must:
    * pass through the first gate (no points, but starts clock), then
    * get the hose coupler up to around the height of the standpipe (1 point), then
    * get the hose coupler aligned well enough to the standpipe to cause the invisible screw joint to be created (1 point), then
    * rotate hose coupler clockwise until it has traveled at least 1.5cm travel into the screw joint (about 2.38 rotations) (1 point), then
    * open valve by rotating it counterclockwise at least 1 full rotation (1 point).

A variety of changes needed to score during competition (as opposed to qualification).

To try it:

roslaunch atlas_utils vrc_task_2.launch

Move/drag the robot through some gates. There will be a log file, /tmp/vrc_task_1/score.log, with content like this:

# Score data for world vrc_task_2
# Started at: 1366926176.753

# wallTime(sec),simTime(sec),wallTimeElapsed(sec),simTimeElapsed(sec),completionScore(count),falls(count)

The elapsed times (3rd and 4th fields) are the times elapsed from passing through the first gate.

That data will also be published along the way on the ROS topic /vrc_score in a message of type atlas_msgs/VRCScore.

Arena-specific rules:

  • V1: Atlas must pass through the first gate, then the vehicle must pass through the next two gates, then Atlas must pass through the last gate. 1 point per gate.
  • V2: Atlas must pass through the gates in order. 1 point per gate.
  • V3: Atlas must:
    • pass through the first gate (no points, but starts clock), then
    • get the hose coupler up to around the height of the standpipe (1 point), then
    • get the hose coupler aligned well enough to the standpipe to cause the invisible screw joint to be created (1 point), then
    • rotate hose coupler clockwise until it has traveled at least 1.5cm travel into the screw joint (about 2.38 rotations) (1 point), then
    • open valve by rotating it counterclockwise at least 1 full rotation (1 point).

values.description:
This pull request fixes the gains on the vehicle actuators so that tele-operation is largely restored, with some small workarounds required to tele-operate the hand-brake. This is based on the atlas_meshes branch, since the new pelvis allows much more stable seated behavior. It should also be tested with the 

Issues fixed:

* #176, vehicle responsiveness improved
* #124, min_brake_percent parameter added which causes deceleration when no gas is applied

Also, the VRCPlugin was modified to destroy the vehicle joint when changing /atlas/mode so the robot_enter_vehicle topic can be used to put the robot in the vehicle, then setting mode to nominal can test sitting in the car while unpinned.

UPDATE:

* retargeted to atlas_meshes_no_head_cage
* added u_leg collisions to mud_seat list
* merge with default
* Reduce max speed to 4.2 m/s and increase min_brake_percent to 4%
values.title: Fixes to vehicle plugin

This is based on the atlas_meshes branch, since the new pelvis allows much more stable seated behavior. It should also be tested with the

Also, the VRCPlugin was modified to destroy the vehicle joint when changing /atlas/mode so the robot_enter_vehicle topic can be used to put the robot in the vehicle, then setting mode to nominal can test sitting in the car while unpinned.

summary.html:
This pull request fixes the gains on the vehicle actuators so that tele-operation is largely restored, with some small workarounds required to tele-operate the hand-brake. This is based on the atlas_meshes branch, since the new pelvis allows much more stable seated behavior. It should also be tested with the

Issues fixed:

  • #176, vehicle responsiveness improved
  • #124, min_brake_percent parameter added which causes deceleration when no gas is applied

Also, the VRCPlugin was modified to destroy the vehicle joint when changing /atlas/mode so the robot_enter_vehicle topic can be used to put the robot in the vehicle, then setting mode to nominal can test sitting in the car while unpinned.

UPDATE:

  • retargeted to atlas_meshes_no_head_cage
  • added u_leg collisions to mud_seat list
  • merge with default
  • Reduce max speed to 4.2 m/s and increase min_brake_percent to 4%

values.description: This adds the ability to take steps statically, instead of dynamically. It's a more stable behavior than the dynamic walk, but it's sloooooow. Pretty cool though. Enjoy
values.title: Adding static walk to actionlib server and keyboard teleop.

values.description:
To compile, you will need the [tactile branch](#!/osrf/sandia-hand/src/4ae87dd997d6c9d36840f7ab962a77a6de1f71e3/?at=tactile) in sandia_hand repo

The locations of the tactile sensors are an approximation of their positions in the spec sheet, but mostly made to fit on our current sandia hand collisions. The range of tactile sensor output values are determined after playing around with the actual sensors on the sandia hand.

Data are published on:

`/sandia_hands/r_hand/tactile_raw` 

`/sandia_hands/l_hand/tactile_raw`

 Also modified the sandia hand to use an imu sensor for generating imu data
values.title: Add tactile sensor to sandia hand, and change imu data generation

values.description:
This implements the support for version 2 of Korg nanokontrol using the same script that works for version 1.

* Only first MIDI mode is implemented (seems enough for our current applications)
* Compatibility for mapping buttons with version 1 is enabled by default

It requires testing with version 1 before get merged.
values.title: Support for version 2 of nanokontrol

summary.raw:
This implements the support for version 2 of Korg nanokontrol using the same script that works for version 1.

* Only first MIDI mode is implemented (seems enough for our current applications)
* Compatibility for mapping buttons with version 1 is enabled by default

It requires testing with version 1 before get merged.
summary.html:
This implements the support for version 2 of Korg nanokontrol using the same script that works for version 1.

  • Only first MIDI mode is implemented (seems enough for our current applications)
  • Compatibility for mapping buttons with version 1 is enabled by default

It requires testing with version 1 before get merged.

values.reason: On hold until VRC is done

values.description:
Upgrade to SDF 1.4. Partial integration of pull request #205.

I had to make a new mesh for the gate and a tiled grass plane to prevent the multi-sense camera from dropping to a low frame rate. 

To see all the changes, you'll need the following pull-requests:
https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/496/allow-uri-to-be-used-when-specifying/diff
https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/493/terrain-improvements
https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/34/use-normal-maps-properly-updated-starting/diff


**Gate**

Made a collada mesh, and added a new text

**Grass Plane**

Created a set of tile for the grass. Grass plane has lower coefficients of friction.

**Gate Numbers**

Increased their visibility

**vrc_task_1.world**

Smoothed out the terrain. Made high friction collisions for the road.

**vrc_task_3.world**

Only a partial update to this world. Switch from using a `grass_plane` to a `pavement_plane`.
values.title: VRC Task 1 updates

values.description:
Switched to use mud model 

Depends on [this pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/497/contact-changes-for-mud-performance/diff) in Gazebo repo for performance improvement. It makes use of the new `collide_without_contact_bitmask` tag
